He said just one thing: "Kill their leader."
The villagers ran down the mountain road, screaming.
There once was a boy who dreamed of becoming a hero.\nAfter serious training and with no shortage of tenacity, he defeated an evil monster that attacked his village and achieved his dream.
"Praise the village hero!"\n"You're the pride of our people!"\n"Please protect us!"

"More monsters? They're no match for our hero!"
"Defeating monsters every day is so easy for you, huh?"
"Your mother's depending on you, you know!"
"..."
Eventually, the pressure became too much for the hero. He became a monster himself.\nHe was so strong that nobody could defeat him.\nThat is...until there came a boy who dreamed of becoming a hero.
I found a chattering sensation,\nthrobbing and pulsating.
It was akin to swaying on a small boat.\nThere's a destination, but no reason for the voyage. \nYou'll never reach it anyway.

Next thing you know, your body is soaking wet.
Drown in it. Each step is overflowing with feeling. 
*Splish splash*
Each step is overflowing with feeling.

It makes the body wet...
Whose tears are these? Whose saliva and secretions?
Whose blood? Whose brains?
Everyone ends up soaking wet.

A woman fell for a man with a shadowy past.\nHe deflected every inquiry into his history and immediately change the subject. Still, it did not matter to the woman. His caress alone was enough to feel loved.

Over time, he bared his emotional scars to her and revealed that both of his parents had been devoured by a werewolf. When she said, "I want to get revenge for your parents," he snapped, "I'll do it. A woman like you shouldn't be out at night."

But she did not heed him.
There was a full moon, and the woman heard a baleful howl in the distance.
Without thinking, she ran outside.
It was then that she saw him.
The one who had wounded the heart of her beloved. She understood instantly that she was no match for it.
Worse still, she realized her beloved and the monster were one in the same.

"Foolish woman. I was only keeping you alive to use you." The line was rehearsed, perfected, proving the werewolf as horrific inside as he was out.\nHis beloved pulled the trigger, ending the creature in an instant. She no longer fears the wolf...
There once was a man whose horrible features hid a gentle heart. The villagers, shallow and cruel, could not see his inner beauty.\nInstead, they viewed him as a threat and ostracized him.
A girl met the man by chance.\nHer mother had succumbed to illness, and she had gotten lost while picking the wild plants needed to heal her.\nIt was here that she met the hideous man.

He went out and gathered the plants for her.\nShe was so grateful that she began to worship him as a demigod. After that, the two of them became friends.\nIn time, the friendship gave rise to a rumor of a demigod who kidnapped young girls.

One day, when the girl went to visit the man,
she found him dead, impaled upon a spear.
In his bestial hand, she found a poorly scribbled note. "Thank you for being my friend."
That's right. He wanted to spare her the hardship of his affections.

"Grandpa... Thank you. I'll be strong during the operation," she said as she gently caressed my wooden head.\nThose were her last words to me.\nIt's no use. My poor magic was only able to provide enough amusement to ease her pain.

If I'm still alive, then she should be, too.\nAt that moment I couldn't help but be reminded of my creator. He gave me life so hers would be protected, but it was still cut short. She used to tell me how she dreamed of healing others...

To be perfectly honest, I don't care about healing anyone. I just inherited her wish to repay her for what she had done for me. That's it.\nBut talking to the people I've met has changed me.\nI've grown frustrated with my inability to save patients.

My old man puppet form was not enough to heal her illness.
But it did provide her comfort in her final days.
On the day of my creator's funeral, many who received his help gathered to say goodbye.
The power of their emotions entered his unfinished puppets, which then became the legacy of his work.

There was a man who acted outside the normal boundaries of society. He once found a bug in peril. Most people who see a dying bug either pass by or kill it. One or the other.\nBut this man chose a third option.\nHe nursed the dying insect back to health.
When the bug recovered, it wanted to repay the man for his help. The tiny creature asked what he most desired.\n"I want a gorgeous harp that sounds better than anything I could afford," he replied.

The bug flew off, and the man followed.
He soon came upon the harp of his dreams.
The man was delighted and told his friend, a fellow musician, what happened.
His friend tried to acquire an instrument in the same manner, but instead discovered that wishes are only granted for selfless acts.

The wretched musician hatched a plan to murder his friend and take the harp for himself. He attacked in the night.\nBut when he did, the violin transformed into a swarm of insects that entered through his rear and ate him, inside out.\nHe died in utter agony.
[History]\nSince medieval times, magic has been prohibited for fear of insurrection. Magic was taken from Richgard as if it never existed at all.
[Technology]\nA small group of individuals were chosen to research it.\nThe majority of the nation's citizens know nothing about steam technology.

[Administration]
A one-party political system. The party leader tends to be afraid of insurrection.
Defensive systems are not built to protect the nation from the outside.
They are strong against internal threats and weak against external threats.

[Activism]\nThe citizens have no weapons of their own and are desperate for ways to repel external threats.\nLabor that can be controlled with automata controllers has gained traction, and relevant research has risen in recent years.
===Town Crier===\nOverpopulation brought humanity to the brink of starvation.\nOur hero saved us with the People Selection Order. "■％■＆■■"

===Town Crier===
The evil people who inherited our hero's dream brought about worldwide chaos once again.
Having sanctioned the capital, our trusty knight made his triumphant return.
All hail the great Tajir!!

===Town Crier===
Fellow countrymen.
A new hero has come to carry the banner of the old.
Listen to the words of the great Tajir!

Fellow countrymen! The evil motives of the capital are no more!
But that is far from a promise of peace.
The lawless tribes that run rampant on our wastelands must all be destro—

*Shhht* We interrupt this broadcast for a rendition of the national anthem.*Shhht*
There once was a lantern created by a lustful god.\nIt would grant all its user's sexual desires for 30 days in exchange for their appetite.
Once, a man used it to summon all the nation's prostitutes, making them slaves to their new master. They were forbidden from eating or grooming.

Another depraved soul got his hands on the lantern. He used it to gather the nation's young and beautiful women, lining them up side by side and carefully examining them.\nNo girl ate for a whole month.
After 30 days, he was satisfied.\nHis sexual desires were sated and his lustful appetite had vanished. All he wanted now was to sleep. Seeking that god's power, he set off on a journey.

There was once a family of master blacksmiths known as the Sword's Scabbard.
They prospered from their intimate relationship with master swordsmen.
The heads of the household were traditionally women. This was the family's custom.
Anyone who became head of household needed to dedicate their life to forging swords for masters of the dueling and killing arts.

The master swordsman of the day was a free-spirited man, but he respected his missions and lived for the sword. The head of the Sword's Scabbard could not accept this.\nShe wanted him to devote everything to her, to forget his blade if only for awhile. More than anything, she yearned to bond with him in the most intimate way possible.

If not for his mission... She wanted nothing but to tie him up and bind them together, forever. Because of this, she gave up her human form and became the master's new sword.
"He'll look at me if I'm a blade."
"He'll never leave me if I'm his sword."
So convinced was she that she offered up her soul for the transformation.

The swordsman died on the battlefield.\nBefore the heavens could collect his soul, chains sprang from the sword, binding itself to the corpse. It was as if it said, "now we'll be together forever," before sucking the man's soul into the blade.\nAt that moment, the blade shimmered and changed color to that of a bellflower.
There once was a rod created by a gluttonous god.\nIt would grant any edible desires to the user for 30 days in exchange for their ability to sleep.

One person who got his hands on it used its power to order the nation's chefs to prepare 108 dishes for him.\n"Keep them coming, day and night," he would say.\nHe ate for 30 days straight without sleeping.

Another man who acquired the rod sought out the world's delicacies. He used the rod's power to amass a fortune to buy white truffles, donkey cheese, and other rare treats that he consumed for 30 days without rest.
After the month was up, he was satisfied.\nHe'd eaten his fill and had no desire to sleep. All he wanted now was sex.\nSeeking a new god's power, he set off on a journey.

There once existed a magical bow.\nIf an archer shot someone with it, the body part they hit could be exchanged for their own. A woman who acquired the enchanted weapon had one desire.\nNot being very attractive herself, she wanted to win the heart of a one man who was kind to her.

She asked the man, "What is your ideal woman?"\n"A woman with blue eyes," he replied.\nShe immediately found the woman with the bluest eyes in the village and shot her with the bow, stealing the eyes for herself.

The next day, she asked him the same question.\n"A woman with long, soft hair." Later he would go on to say, "A woman who is pure of heart." Once again, she fired arrow after arrow, crafting herself into his ideal vision of womanhood.

The next day, she had planned to ask the man the question once again.
However, having become pure of heart, she realized the wrongs she'd committed.
"I'll never be the woman he wants."
She took her own life, her final lament carried away on the wind.

Once there were two brothers who were the most famous craftsmen in the country. Their skill was such that almost everyone who saw their work would say, "I would kill for something they've made."\nHowever, while they were certainly skilled, they were also unbelievably stupid.

The brothers were close, but their opinions often differed when it came to weapons.
When shouting could be heard from their home, the townsfolk would smile and say,
"Here we go again," and "Listen to them go!"
Being as idiotic as they were, the brothers never noticed they were being watched.

One day, they were arguing over spears.
"An excellent spear needs only one thing," insisted the older brother.
"A point sharp enough to pierce anything," The younger brother interjected. 
"That won't do any good if it breaks in battle," he said, insisting on the merits of durability. They came up with the idea of making a spear that possessed both traits.

They soon made their idolized weapon a reality.\nWhen they tried to display the spear in their storefront, truth dawned on them.\nThe spear was so heavy that they couldn't even lift it. It was just a good-for-nothing clump of iron. It stayed where it was long after the brothers died.
There once was a fair and capable hunter in a mountain village.\nThe village girls loved him.\nEveryone constantly sought his attentions.

In this same village, there was a very inquisitive man.
The woman he fancied was also smitten with the hunter.
Jealous, the man followed the hunter in hopes of discovering the other man's weakness.
The hunter entered a field of white flowers and began to pluck his harp.

The man couldn't believe what happened next.\nIn response to the sound of the harp, the flowers transformed into beautiful women.\nThrilled to have discovered the hunter's secret, he began to head home.

But he didn't get very far. Before the curious man could react, several pairs of hands wrapped tight around his neck. He fell, entangled in a forest of white limbs.\nAs he faded out of consciousness, he finally understood why the hunter's secret had long been preserved...
"Destroy the heathens." The voice echoed in the back of my head.\nDissonance. The gun's words. My reason for being...
I shake it off. It was a grim notion. It had nothing to do with morality.\nIt was clear a sacrifice had to be made.
I feel constricted when the gun is in my hand. It's unpleasant.\nI feel tight all over.\nYet I cannot abandon my quest to purge those bastard heathens from the land.
My hands are covered in blood.\nI vividly recall the agony of death. The smell of smoke burns my nostrils.\n"I killed them. I killed them all." I was proud of that, at least.
If nothing else, I was safe.\nAfter how badly I was injured,\nit's a miracle I managed to survive.
To be honest, I hated it at first.\nBut at some point,\nI started to feel comfortable in that cramped space.
The sound of a harp. That means he's home.\nI sing along to it. The sounds echo through the stifling room and resonate.\nIn a moment, I forget about our differences.

In time, my wounds healed.
Our last day together. His tone was filled with the deepest sorrow.
He seemed loath to part with me.
But we made our duet last into the night.

I can't read this book. I don't even know why I can't read it.
It's not written in a foreign language or anything. I just can't grasp it.
All these pictures displaying such spectacular images...
I can only imagine what stories are trying to be told.

Every day I tried to read this book, and I became further absorbed by it.
1 year. 2 years. 3 years... The flow of time is cruel.
10 years have passed, and I still can't read it...
Just when I was about to give up, it happened.

I could somehow read the book, despite years of ignorance!
I was ecstatic. I could finally see. And I was so infinitely disappointed.
Despite the lyrical prose, it was full of nothing but insanity.
Yes... That's it. It's little more than waffling nonsense.

"That's it?!" I was so angry I threw the book aside.
But as I did, I found a new page on the back cover.
These sentences were even harder than the others.
I could only imagine what these fascinating stories were trying to tell...
Quiet your heart and pray to the gods.
The sounds of a sinful world disappear,\nand your head is filled with words of divinity.
Surrender yourself\nand give praise.
When the gods hear your prayer,\ntheir white lightning will strike down evil where it stands.

Once, a country on the verge of collapse created a magical crimson sword by sacrificing maidens from across the land. The sword had several curses on it and was said to cut down anything that entered the user's periphery.

A master swordsman who came into possession of this famous blade was its natural caretaker.\nHe did not fear the voices he heard from the sword and often talked with them.\nThe maidens inside trusted him for his sincerity and began to tell him why they sacrificed themselves for the sword.
It occurred to the master that all of the maidens had tasks left undone.\nFrom that day forward, he began fulfilling their wishes and dispelling their attachments to the mortal world.
When he had finally fulfilled the last of their tasks, the sword's curses were lifted, and the blade became so sharp that nothing it cut would ever suffer.

A demon, known as an Oni, was trying to destroy a country. Lamenting the doom to befall his lands, the king issued a decree: "Enough money to last three generations will be awarded to anyone who slays the beast."

Rumors circulated around the proposed destruction of the fiend.\nPeople began to whisper that the king had ordered a hammer strong enough to defeat the Oni once and for all. The hammer could sense an Oni disguised as a human, and it was so powerful that it could obliterate the demon with a single stroke.

Initially, the Oni's ability to shapeshift made it incredibly difficult to find.\nDistrustful of their neighbors, citizens began to plot ways to obtain the hammer.\nIt was around that time that it was said to have been seen in the plaza.

The rush of people who advanced on the plaza from all over the country caused complete chaos.
Everyone was killing each other for the hammer.
The Oni, hidden in the crowd, could only smile with enjoyment.
He had placed the hammer there, knowing the result of human nature.
How powerless they were.

There was once a man who did not know what to do.
His debt was increasing by the day, and he could barely make ends meet.
He needed money, and fast, so he decided to become a mercenary, kill an enemy general, and cash in on the bounty.
Though he was a lazy man, he said to himself, "At least it's better than dying."
He headed to the forest to practice with his bow.

Just then, a hungry beast emerged from a thicket. Fearing that the beast might eat him, he gave it some bread.\nThe beast was so grateful that it broke off one of its teeth and gave it to the man. The beast told him that if he attached the fang to his bow, it would bestow a blessing of flawless accuracy.

The man's mind was finally at ease. He celebrated with a small dance and made his way to the battlefield. The effect was exactly as the beast had said. Despite being a novice, he was able to kill the general without issue and collect his reward.

The man was finally able to turn his life around.
He now had a way to make money.
He would head to the forest and fire a number of arrows. When he followed the arrows' trajectories, he found that each and every one had felled a beast.
The man would bring corpses back and use them to strengthen his bow. It's a shame that his success felled his savior.
The spear had a will of its own.\nWhen a man took it out of the cramped and putrid cellar in which it had been stored, the spear was immensely grateful.

The spear was driven by it's own emotions.\nSo much was the weapon's gratitude that it refused to allow the man's gentle hands to caress anyone else. The spear knew he only had eyes for it and was fiercely jealous of others.
The spear could use magic to move on its own.\nWhen it went flying straight toward the back of a woman the man cherished, he put the weapon back in storage out of fear.
There the spear slept until it was awoken from it's long slumber.\nIt had always been quick to fall in love.\nIt didn't matter one bit that its new master was a woman.
A boy picked up the flute by the river, but quickly went into a daze as if possessed. His parents couldn't understand why he would play horribly out of tune well into the night.
He suddenly showed rapid improvement\nand earned the respect of a great musician.\nAfter that, his parents lauded him as a genius.
Though the boy was pure, he desperately craved praise. He continued to play the flute and asked of his listeners, "Hey! That was good, right? See how much better I've gotten?"

The talent to make such beautiful music came at a price.
The flute was fueled with the wailing cries of those who were about to die.
The boy killed many people, all for the sake of greater praise.
More and more and more more more—there was no limit to the slaughter.

There once was a humble boy who had no friends.\nOne day, perhaps to make fun of him, another boy from a wealthy family gave him a seemingly useless tome from the family archives. The boy was so grateful that he took it home and cared for his precious gift.

The tome was full of blank white pages.\nDespite this, the boy spoke to the book year after year, treasuring it. One day, the blank book revealed a story that enthralled the boy. He decided to follow the protagonist's lead and study magic.

In time, he began to take pride in his new abilities. It was around then that he became indispensable to those around him, just like the hero in the story.\nThough he had already attained his dream of friendship, he continued to take good care of the book. The only thing he wanted to know was...how the story ended.

One day, he received an imperial command.
While he was on his way to intercept the target, he decided to open the tome for the first time in a while.
"Ah... The ending is my favorite part."
The final page, once blank, now told of the man's death.

There once was a wizard whom many believed would be the next great sage.\nIn that country, such wise men were viewed as national heroes. Every year, people anxiously awaited the festival that would decide who would be heralded as the next sage.
Naturally, nationwide festivals tend to loosen the purse strings of their citizens.\nEvery year, people would bet on who would be appointed as sage, and great sums of money would move hands.

One man was the favorite to win that year.
When he went to perform his magic for the king,
the room buzzed with excitement.
But when he attempted to show the king what he could do, the shimmer of his staff suddenly died out,
and he was left gazing up at the sky.

Amidst the boos and hisses, the man looked in astonishment at the woman who had nominated him for sage. She was a suspicious peddler who had pushed him to buy his staff.\nIn the end, the least favored person became sage, and the victor was given riches and fame beyond compare.
I desperately pounded on the door.\nUnhealthy and thin, I was invited in by a well-known clergyman.
I would give anything for this man.\nMy body. My family. Even my own life.\nHe was like a god to me.
He began ordering me to kill people for him. How many times had it been?\nI failed my first mission... But I was sure it'd be okay.\nI was sure he would forgive me...
But that was wishful thinking.\n"Kill her," he spat, pointing to a girl who looked\njust like I used to long ago.

There once was a girl who lived in an unforgiving land.
When she was six, she was tricked by her debt-ridden mother, who sold her into slavery.
Her mother, ugly and irresponsible, was horrified.
The girl returned, covered in blood and consumed with the knowledge that violence was power.

When she grew up, she felt something beyond her power was lacking.\nMen would try to seduce her by saying it was arousal that she lacked. The gloomy woman took it to heart and realized how useful it could be. She used her beautiful body to seduce men in an effort to pull herself from the darkness.

How many families did she fall in with after that?
Her last conquest was the heir to a famous company.
"I wonder how my beloved's face will look next time he's yelling at me?"
The question popped into her head again and again.

The answer came one day when he presented her with a fake sword.
Telling of the weapon's origin, he noted, "A sword has but one purpose."
She drew the sword. The next thing she knew, he was yelling at her. "The despair of those who bow to my superiority! That's what brings me joy!"
The last thing she saw was him kissing her slowly severed body.

There once was a fiery man in an empire full of steam.\nBecause he valued his comrades' lives over the destruction of his enemies, he was never promoted and remained a lowly soldier.\nStill, he never wavered, and the people loved him for it. They would send letters praising the man's passion, honor, and temperament.

One day, he sat amongst white flowers by the lake and mourned his fallen comrades as he always did.
A woman he had never seen before was watching him.
How long had she been there? Overcome by curiosity, he talked with the mysterious woman.
She spoke of how she was expected to carry out missions without emotion.

They met for the fifth time on a night when the moon was full.
The girl was awkward, but she smiled for the first time and bid him farewell.
Though he missed her, he woke up with a sense of satisfaction the next morning.
But he was soon filled with dread.
Loss and despair transformed him when he was told the girl had been killed on her mission.

Kill! Kill! Kill some more!
The man disobeyed his superiors and went to where she fell.
Soon, he was in the same dangerous land that had taken her life.
He could feel emotions die within him, but he just kept killing.
When he finally destroyed the last of his enemies, the man was totally void of the emotions the girl had loved.

Deep, deep in the forest
rested a long forgotten spear.
Its owner was a girl that
loved the woods more than anything.

The forest meant the world to her.\nWhen she heard it was going to be burned down and converted into farmland, she vowed to fight all who dare strike a match to it.\nShe might have only been one person, but she was not alone in her fight.

She banded together with others who lived in the forest and resisted. Her opponents were persistent, and eventually, their organized and concentrated invasion proved too much.\nThe girl and her allies were burned along with the forest.

In time, the land reverted and grew wild.
In the heart of a clearing, almost as if it were an offering, stood a single spear.
Even now, the birds she loved
flock to it and sing a mournful song.

When a girl plucked the cursed harp, she was given a place in life. She resisted it at first, but in the end, she came to celebrate it.\nYou see, to honor a promise she made to a dying friend, she decided to perform. And so, she lived the life of a harp player at the carnival.
"There can be no doubt. Understand that if you continue to play such an ill-fitting role, you must face the consequences," she reminded herself every day.
Urged on by her harp, she continued to captivate audiences. That was the role she was given—an entertainer. She fulfilled her promise to her dead friend "to become a famous musician."

Those consequences came at long last.
A gunshot interrupted her performance.
The palace guards had shot a demon who tricked people with its music.
It's said that her corpse was surrounded by the bodies of those listeners whose spirits had been absorbed by the harp.

December 8th. Sunny.
I want those eyes to pierce me through.
The loyalty I swore to the blade has all been overshadowed by desire...
Oh, if only I meant something to the princess.

December 13th. Downpour.
A blessed rain. This will wash away the footprints and erase all evidence of my crime.
Oh, my beloved princess.
I'll be by your side soon enough. I'm finally ready to put my plan into action, but my hands won't stop shaking.

December 18th. Snowfall.
An extremely cramped room. Disheveled clothes.
Skin as white as porcelain. Her frightened eyes.
A single swing of the sword. I press the edge, not the tip, against her skin.
The cold iron steals the warmth from her body...

December 18th. Snowfall.
The princess only has eyes for me.
Her outstretched hands seek my warmth.
Oh, princess.
We're together. Now and forever...

Chronological Record (1)\nA massive database which contained all the aggregated historical data spanning multiple generations throughout the world. It was created in part by advancements in network technology spanning back to the Gamania Empire.

Chronological Record (2)\nIn the current generation, data is mainly input through manual means. However, historical modifications have not occurred due to the presence of Oracle Knights in the imperial administration ministry.

Chronological Record (3)\nCurrently, effects resulting from history modification are picked up only by the system's detection functions,\nwhere backdoor vulnerabilities still remain. In the future, these problems are expected to be solved through automated input methods.
Chronological Record (4)\nIn order to ensure that the automated input function is a success, all members with the ability to modify history have been installed with a Shell Box.
It was a feast to celebrate victory over our greatest foes.\nHowever, despite the excitement and cheer, I sat dead-eyed with a heart overburdened by sorrow.\nThese feelings began to take their toll.
Just 1,000 hours until the link was established.\nEssentially, that meant the fabric which held together the person I knew as "myself" would untangle.\nWho I was would cease to exist.
I used to think that, if it were to protect the world from utter annihilation, being manipulated and eventually killed was justifiable.

The day I was to lose myself had long since passed.
I've realized that my lived experiences offered me a real
but fleeting joy that I could not throw away.
I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I'm sorry.
With one look it was easy to see that this blade had an unrivaled edge. However, the swordsman felt something was amiss, as it was obvious this sword had yet to taste the blood of battle.

The skeptical swordsman asked the hawker about the item. "Has this sword seen battle?" he wondered. The hawker reassured the swordsman it must have, considering the blade had been around since his grandfather's time.

The swordsman carefully examined the sword.\nThere, he noticed that not only had it a sharp edge, but it also contained a magic catalyst, peerless in design. This dark magic was sealed in the hilt and could amplify the sword's strength by absorbing the wielder's magic power.

"This is indeed quite the item..." murmured the swordsman as he rushed home with his new possession.\nHowever, the hawker had neglected to inform him that each swing required a complex spell. Regardless, the hawker quickly left town after selling his stock of defective wares.

Some tales live on while others fade away.\nOne unremarkable day in a far-off land, the voice of a princess rang clear throughout the country. She greeted the early risers, saying "There are only ten more days till destruction. Please, let us enjoy each precious remaining day as best we can."
Without a moment's notice, the ever-affectionate and kind-hearted princess then cast a spell to alter the citizens' perception of time so they may spend the rest of their days without regret.

Torchbearers were tasked to light the night so that worrisome thoughts could not hide in the shadows, and chefs were tasked to prepare delicious feasts. The country seemingly worked together to fulfil the princess's wish of having her people happy till the very end.
Finally, the fated day came.\nHowever, not a soul was in despair when the cleansing light eradicated the country, as the princess had purposefully lied about when the end of the world would come.

There once was a band of knights that was the embodiment of all that was pure and righteous.\nThey received massive tributes from the people. Instead of using their wealth on their own desires, they lent it to pilgrims and the royal family, acquiring many assets in the process.

Eventually, more than half the land belonged to the knights.
Others began to overlook their just nature
and considered them a blight on the nation.
The knights' biggest mistake was underestimating how much they were despised.

With time, corrupt aristocrats set their sights on the knights' assets, falsely accusing them of many crimes.\nThe knights were deprived of their private property and sentenced to death by public execution.\nThe knight captain, despite his righteousness, showered the firing squad with words of hate and resentment as they aimed and fired.

Later, when asked what happened to those that condemned the knights, people who knew shook with fear and said that the knights cursed them.\nThey claimed that the townspeople were found dead... They all had holes punched through their skulls.

There once were twin sisters who loved each other very much. Whatever the younger sister did, the older sister could do better. Still, the younger sister tried her hardest not to fall behind, and the older sister adored her for it.

But happiness has a way of slipping all too quickly.
After their parents were poisoned by political rivals,
the sisters were forced to live in the slums. All the younger sister could do was cry.
The older sister resigned herself to sacrificing everything to protect her little sister.
She would be her guardian angel.

The older sister sat in silence, her expression vacant, suffering from starvation.
It had been 10 days since she gave her little sister the last of their bread.
She could think of nothing else but of that last slice.
She didn't want to think ill of her sister,
but hatred welled up inside her for that burdensome little wench.

The older sister muttered obscenities to herself. When the younger sister begged for food, the older sister stabbed her repeatedly.
"Finally," she grumbled, "You're making yourself useful!"
The older sister gorged herself on her sibling's body.
Her younger sister alone was not enough to sate her, however.
She continued to eat person after person until a guard shot her straight through the heart.

There was once a poor servant girl who worked every day god sent.
Her husband was a bad and violent man.
But she loved him, so his days were good.
Nothing would make her happier after finishing work to play her flute in the forest.

One morning out in the forest, the housemaid came across a fairy. It asked her if she could play her reed pipe for its friend, since it was their birthday. She declined at first, afraid she'd be punished for abandoning her duties. But when the fairy begged and pleaded so desperately, the housemaid could not say no.

The fairies were captivated by the housemaid's beautiful music. They urged her to play for one more day, and of course the housemaid declined...at first. After much insisting, she finally caved in and played for another day.

As a show of appreciation, the fairies turned her reed pipe into an enchanted blue pipe.
When she returned home, the housemaid knocked timidly on the door, fearing her fate.
A woman she had never seen before opened it.
It seems time passed differently in the forest,
and her violent master had passed away during the two years she was gone.
What goes up, must come down.\nThe same goes for our thoughts and our time spent together.
I know it's not what you wanted.\nTrust me. I know.\nAnd honestly, I wish you could have made it.
By channeling all of my energy into this staff,\nI'll possess a power that transcends all that was thought humanly possible...\nEven if it's for only a moment.
I know what I'm doing is wrong.\nBut this is my only option. I have no regrets.

Vengeance knows no bounds.
The swordsman understood that well.
His heart craved it.
His father would be avenged.

He wasn't always a swordsman.\nWhen he was young, his father was murdered by a dragon, forcing his mother to raise him on her own.\nEvery night, he vowed to take vengeance on the dragon and to bring closure to his mother's broken heart.

The boy trained and trained, until he became a master swordsman.\nConfident in his skill, he set out for the dragon's nest to avenge his father.\nHe regretted leaving his wife and child to pursue his prey, but the vengeance in his heart was stronger than the love for his family.

The dragon and the swordsman blamed each other for their father's death.\nThe dragon's talons ripped through the swordsman, tearing him asunder.\nThe dragon roared, blinded by fury, for it too was a prisoner of vengeance.

"Veteran"
Since times of old,
only those that returned
from countless battles were worthy of such a title.

"Veteran"
May it never be regarded as merely a title,
for it is a brand created through the sacrifices of fallen brothers,
forged from the ashes of millions of soldiers.
"Veteran"\nThe wound left behind those branded as "veteran" never heals,\nas the rest of their waking lives holds no purpose besides atonement.
With pride in their hearts and tears in their eyes,\nveterans leave their beloved armaments on the battlefield.\nThese ageless weapons of war lie in wait for the next battle to begin.
When I let the music move me, I become more beautiful than anyone can imagine.
I'm seen as a diva.\nMy audience is constantly defiling me...in their minds, anyway. "I may not be able to touch her in real life," they think, "But I can do whatever I want to her in my head."
People in power always tell me how much they want me.\nMoney is no object to them. Every night, they turn into lustful beasts with insatiable sexual appetites.
Those who don't know the pleasures of defilement\nwould have no interest in a diva like me.

Once upon a time there was a wizard who lived with his wife.\nThey owned land, and their assets increased every year.\nBut fortune has a habit of disappearing when you need it most. When a drought struck their village, the man decided to visit the local spring to dedicate a prayer to the water spirit.

The prayer was heard. The water spirit appeared. "Don't worry," it said.\n"I'll grant you a bountiful harvest of the likes you've never seen. There's just one condition... You must give me that which is most important to you."

The man was prepared to lose all of his land as long as he could return home knowing that the village was saved.
A midwife greeted him when he returned home.
"Congratulations," she said. "You have a son."
The man now understood the water spirit's true intentions. So he grabbed his staff and headed back to the spring.

"I'll never give you my son," he declared, casting a spell.\n"Then I'll take what's most important to you in this moment," the water spirit countered, taking the man's weapon and killing him.\nThe water spirit then fed upon the man's oh so sweet offering of "despair."

-Foreword-
I came upon a bit of sorcery while writing this book.
It allows me to view footage of the future.
I must express my deep respect and gratitude to Wolf, the magnificent mage.
P.1 Versailles\n・Location: Japan\n・Features: A room illuminated with beautiful colors.
P2. Treasured Guest House\n・Location: Japan\n・Features: A room equipped with various torture devices.
-Afterword-\nHow incredibly sad.\nSuch open and free sexuality running rampant through the palace could bring the world to ruin. We must do everything We can to avoid this dark future.

There once was a dragon that strayed from his kin and fell into a trap. A boy who had just happened to be passing by freed the dragon.\n"No one else would free me from my loneliness," thought the dragon. So the dragon followed his savior wherever he went.

The boy's parents insisted that the young dragon obey him, no matter what. If the dragon could promise that, they'd allow the boy to keep him. The dragon, not wanting to be alone again, agreed. He took his promise very seriously.

Just as the boy was growing into a strong young man, a war broke out. He was conscripted into the military.\n"Don't leave the house," he told the dragon, hoping to protect him. "I'll be back before you know it." And with that, he left to join the war.

It was a promise he seemed unlikely to keep. The young man was captured by the enemy. When the time came for his execution, the boy remembered the dragon waiting for him back home. "I'm sorry I couldn't keep my promise," said the boy. Just then, the clouds parted and a winged beast swooped down to his rescue.\nThe dragon hadn't kept his promise, either...

It happens all the time.\nNoble families fall, and their children resort to theft to get by. One such child, a boy, saw stealing as his only means of survival. So when a shopkeeper who knew of the boy's past showed him mercy, it brought a smile to his face.

As time went by, a new lord came to rule over the land.\nFearing poverty, the lord levied taxes on the people. He saw taxes as the only way he could maintain his wealth.\nThe people resisted. They had two choices—die fighting or die starving.

Around this time, an old man was shot. While this, too, was a normal occurrence, what happened next wasn't.\nThe lord ran to the old man, and did what he could to save him.\nIt was the old shopkeeper whom had helped the lord when he was but a poor boy.
In time, the old man recovered.\nThe lord, remembering his childhood in poverty,\nhad a change of heart. The dagger that connected them would symbolize the bond between lord and vassal.
And just like that, my freedom was gone.\nI found myself confined to a tiny cell. I couldn't even flap my wings. I spent my days singing, yearning for the endless blue skies.

The boys and girls and their repulsive smiles...\nThey watched me. I cried and cried, having lost my reason for being. As if to assert their authority over me, they responded to my wailing by giving me food and water.

The next thing I knew, I was flying freely above the clouds.
I wanted to fly up into the sun and end my life to make sure that I'd never end up in that dark place again.
But you can't kill yourself if you're only dreaming.
I gradually grew weak and died in deep despair.

The boys and girls cried.
Perhaps because they realized it was impossible to hate me. For their final act of humiliation, they plucked my feathers and attached them to arrows.
"Now we'll be together forever."
The innocently smiling children were nothing more than demons.
The boy wanted nothing more than for his nagging grandfather to die just a little bit sooner. As if to grant that wish, his grandfather died peacefully soon after the boy reached adulthood.
The boy was surprised.\nTo him, his grandfather was larger than life. There's no point to life if it's a life lived alone. Desperate, the boy decided to try his luck on the battlefield.
The boy wielded a hammer\nhis grandfather had lovingly named "Old Friend."\nHe swung it haphazardly at the enemy with reckless abandon.

The boy wasn't accustomed to battle, making him an easy target.
A single arrow found its mark.
As he died, a voice spoke to him from the hammer. "Foolish boy! The battlefield is no place for an idiot like you!"
It was the voice of his departed grandfather.

She could hurt others and never feel any remorse.
This is how she earned a living.
One person. Five. Twenty? She didn't have enough fingers to count them all.
Then, one day, it happened. She met a man like herself.
He dreamt of pain, and continued to kill in hopes of one day feeling the agony he craved.

Impressed, she decided to follow his lead.\nLike him, she hoped to someday feel anguish over all the killing she'd done. There seemed to be no reason she shouldn't experience the same remorse as everyone else. But like some kind of sick joke, she never did.
She met the man who shared her curse once again.\n"Perform my last rites," he said.\nHaving killed so many without the slightest shred of remorse, the man wanted to end his life.

Having done as he asked, the woman felt a tear slide down her cheek.\n"So this is pain... It hurts. It feels like my heart is about to be ripped in two..."\nFinally human, the woman didn't miss what she used to be. She cheerfully chased others like herself until the end of her days...

A light that erodes bodies. A stream of that light enveloped me.
I was sure it would spell my end.
I could feel it.
I couldn't control my magic and became a nuisance to everyone around me.
It's not like I was the most popular person in the village to begin with.
There was one person in the village willing to put up with me.\nA boy.\nHe called me "beautiful."

In time, the light eroding me became too much for me to hide. The only place left for someone in my state was next to him. Sitting back and listening to him play his harp became the best part of my life.

"That was quick." On the verge of death,
I imbued his harp with the last of my power.
"I want to be with you always."
That was my final wish. But being who I am,
I couldn't help but place a tiny little curse on the harp.
My image pops into the head of anyone who plays it...
